FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.Description:
We take a systematic approach to preventing the accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

?    Process Safety Information
?    Process Hazard Analysis
?    Operating Procedures and Safety Work Practices
?    Training and Performance
?    Mechanical Integrity
?    Quality Assurance
?    Management of Change-Technology
?    Pre-startup Reviews
?    Compliance Audits
?    Incident Investigation and Reporting
?    Employee Participation
?    Hot Work
?    Contractors (Safety and Performance)
?    Management of Change-Personnel
?    Emergency Planning and Response

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to full compliance with these management systems, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.

Our Plant Manager has the overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.  This responsibility includes overseeing the continued implementation of the elements of our Risk Management Program.  To ensure that our Risk Management Program is appropriately maintained, our Plant Manager continues to assign the role of PSM/RMP Coordinator to a member of the plant organization with the necessary background, training and experience to fulfill this position.   The PSM/RMP Coordinator, acting with the authority delegated directly from the Plant Manager, has the responsibility for the continued implementation and integration of the EPA RMP elements and the elements of OSHA?s PSM program.

The PSM/RMP Coordinator serves as the chairman of the facility?s Process Safety and Risk Management Committee, a subcommittee of the site?s Central Safety and Health Committee.   This Committee is comprised of members with responsibilities that include maintaining and upgrading specific elements of our Risk Management and Process Safety Management Programs.  Managing the specific elements of our Risk Management and Process Safety Programs is a line organization function overseen by the Central Safety and Health Committee.   The members of the Process Safety and Risk Management Committee are assigned by the Plant Manager based on recommendations from the PSM/RMP Coordinator.   Currently, the structure of the Process Safety and Risk Management Committee is as follows:

Process Safety and Risk Management Committee (PSRM),
A subcommittee of Central Safety and Health (CS&H)

PSM/RMP Coordinator
?    Process Safety Information Leader
?    Operating Procedures and Safety Work Practices Leader
?    Management of Change Leader
?    Process Hazards Analysis Coordinator
?    Quality Assurance Leader
?    Pre-startup Safety Reviews Leader
?    Mechanical Integrity Leader
?    Training and Performance Leader
?    Contractor Safety and Performance Leader
?    Incident Investigation and Reporting Leader
?    Management of Change ? Personnel Leader
?    Emergency Planning and Response Leader
?    Auditing Leader

The general organizational structure and the lines of authority at the DeLisle Plant for RMP implementation and compliance are as follows:

PLANT MANAGER
   Unit Manager ? Reaction, Purification, Oxidation, Environmental (RPOE)
       Area Manager ? Reaction
       Area Manager ? Purification and Oxidation
       Area Manager - Maintenance
   Unit Manager ? Finishing, Packaging, Distribution (FPD)
       Area Manager ? Finishing
       Area Manager ? Packing and Distribution
       Area Manager - Maintenance
   Engineering Manager
       Area Manager ? Power and Power Maintenance
       Project Manager
       Area Manager ? Operations Support & Contract Administration
   Unit Manager ? Services
       Sr. Safety & Environmental Consultant / PSM/RMP Coordinator
       Safety Team Manager
       Occupational Health Professional
   Research and Development Supervisor

The PSM/RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective, and compliant prevention program that meets EPA RMP and OSHA PSM requirements.   Although the PSM/RMP Coordinator has some specific individual responsibilities, many of the responsibilities for specific program elements are assigned to other members of the Process Safety and Risk Management Committee and the site?s line management organization.

_accidents.CI_OtherType: reinforce with appropriate personnel the requirements in regard to removing personal protective equipment

_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: Vacuum hose being drained of titanium tetrachloride had water introduced

_accidents.CF_Other: Operating procedure did not adequately adress undetected residual material.

_accidents.CI_OtherType: contact railcar owner regarding railcar performance and maintenance

_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: insufficient vacuum in vent system due to valve allowing nitrogen into vent system

_accidents.CF_Other: removed pipe did not have end sufficiently contained

_accidents.CI_OtherType: enhance training to include demonstration of the learnings from this incident

_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: from the flanges on the maintenance vacuum line

_accidents.CI_OtherType: evaluate alternate design or material of construction and evaluate preventative maintenance plan

_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: During routine maintenance, chlorine was released from a disassembled/disconnected flange.
_accidents.CF_Other: An inadequate lockout checklist contributed to an incomplete lockout. The response by the attendant was improper.

_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: Release came as a result of the removal of a storage tank level transmitter stilling chamber that contained TiCl4-laden solids.

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Harrison Co. Local Emerg. Plng Comm

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The DuPont Titanium Technologies (DTT) Plant at DeLisle, Mississippi has a mission statement that includes "safely making" TiO2.   Our mission compliments our community commitment, which is that the community gives us the ?consent to operate? to the extent that we must operate our facilities with the highest standards with the focus on operating excellence.  Our mission and commitment statements reflect the position of our company.   In the DuPont Commitment to Safety, Health and the Environment, it is stated that ?through this commitment to safety, health and environmental excellence we affirm to all our stakeholders, including our employees, customers, shareholders and the public that we will conduct our business with respect and care for the environment.?    To accomplish these aspects of our mission and community commitment, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and environmentally responsible manner.   We use a combinationof accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as the protection of the environment.  DeLisle?s approach to accidental release prevention is to fully comply with OSHA?s PSM rule and DuPont?s standard on Process Safety Management, S21A-PSM.   While complying with the OSHA rule and our own standard, we address all elements of the RMP rule for a Program 3 Prevention Program.

The DuPont Plant at DeLisle, Mississippi is located on the north short of the Bay of St. Louis about 15 miles west of Gulfport, Mississippi.  The facilities are situated on a 2600-acre site; however, only about 200 acres are developed.  We manufacture a single product, titanium dioxide (TiO2), under the trade name TiPure ?.  Titanium dioxide is manufactured via the chloride process in which titanium dioxide ore is chlorinated to titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4); the TiCl4 is subsequently re-oxidized to refined TiO2.  The RMP covered chemi

cals we handle are detailed in the following:

    TOXIC                                     USE AT DELISLE
    Chlorine                              Produce Titanium Tetrachloride
    Titanium Tetrachloride        Intermediate used in the manufacture of TiO2


In the past five (5) years, we have had five (5) accidental releases that resulted in a total of seven (7) OSHA recordable injuries.   The largest release was of 26 pounds of chlorine on November 20, 2000.

DeLisle?s emergency response program is contained in our Emergency Procedures Manual (EPM).  It consolidates the various regulations for emergency response planning.  It provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public and the environment during emergency situations.  We do coordinate our plan with applicable community emergency response plans and local responders.  During an emergency that involves the LEPC, the request for assistance is directed to the Harrison County Sheriff?s Department, who in turn contacts other emergency organizations.  Important keys to the success of our emergency response program include:
   
?    a trained on-site emergency organization,
?    training for all employees, including routine drills,
?    drills and information sharing with local emergency responders and,
?    the use of our Early Warning System (EWS) to alert our near neighbors.

Our Plant Protection Coordinator (PPC) directs on-site response activities.   This position is detailed in Section 1.8 and is filled by four individuals.   They are as follows:
Paul M. (Mickey) Jermyn     [e-mail:  P-Mickey.Jermyn@usa.dupont.com]    
Rod J. Ladner                      [e-mail:  Roderick.J.Ladner@usa.dupont.com]
Mark G. Bland                    [e-mail:  Mark.G.Bland@usa.dupont.com]
Brooke J. Young                     [e-mail:  Brooke.J.Young@usa.dupont.com]

To improve DeLisle?s safety performance and position, we make improvements to plant facilities and systems through various processes.   Some of these are PSM process

es such as process hazards reviews, incident investigations and auditing.   We also make improvements as identified by our DTT PSM Network.   This network has membership from each of our TiO2 production sites.
